title: Investigation into Nancy Guthrie's Disappearance Extends to Mexico
summary: The disappearance of Nancy Guthrie, an 84-year-old woman from Tucson, Arizona, has led to a widespread investigation involving US and Mexican authorities. Reported missing in early February, her case has generated over 40,000 leads, but no breakthrough has occurred despite appeals from her daughter, NBC anchor Savannah Guthrie. US investigators, including the FBI, have contacted Mexican officials in Sonora, suggesting she might have been taken across the border. A Mexican non-profit, Searching Mothers of Sonora, known for handling cases linked to drug cartels, has been enlisted by the family to assist. While ransom notes demanding cryptocurrency have emerged via media outlets like TMZ, officials have not confirmed any abduction by narco-traffickers. The investigation continues with standard cross-border cooperation, focusing on her last known whereabouts and ruling out family involvement.

It highlights the complexities of international investigations, including cooperation between law enforcement agencies and the involvement of non-profits in regions affected by crime. Understanding this case requires knowledge of how missing persons investigations work, the role of media in reporting such events, and the challenges of border security.
